intro: Piper hispidum var. trachydermum, commonly known as the rough-skinned pepper plant, is a variant of the Piper hispidum species native to tropical regions of South America. It is characterized by its hairy, rough-textured stems and leaves, which give it its common name. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that develop into berries, which are often used in local cuisines for their pungent flavor. It thrives in humid, warm climates and is typically grown as a climbing or shrub-like plant. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the Piperaceae family, known for its aromatic and medicinal properties.
